verses.text: Listen to my prayer, O God, do not ignore my plea;
hear me and answer me. My thoughts trouble me and I am distraught

rsbNotes.title: Ps 55
rsbNotes.text: Ps. 55 Like many laments, this psalm bemoans the attack of enemies. Most unusual is the sorrow over betrayal by a friend. The psalm descends to the pits of despair, but turns at the end toward the Lord with hope. The psalm anticipates the suffering of Christ, who was betrayed by Judas, a disciple of His inner circle (Matt. 26:47–56).

verses.text: at the voice of the enemy, at the stares of the wicked; for they bring down suffering upon me and revile me in their anger.
My heart is in anguish within me; the terrors of death assail me.
Fear and trembling have beset me; horror has overwhelmed me.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 55:3
rsbNotes.text: 55:3 enemy. The psalmist refers to enemies in general terms because he knows that his song will be used by other people in other situations (v. 22).

verses.text: I said, "Oh, that I had the wings of a dove! I would fly away and be at rest-
I would flee far away and stay in the desert; Selah
I would hurry to my place of shelter, far from the tempest and storm."

rsbNotes.title: Ps 55:6
rsbNotes.text: 55:6 I would fly away. The writer has the urge to escape the source of his distress, but is unable to do so.

verses.text: Confuse the wicked, O Lord, confound their speech, for I see violence and strife in the city.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 55:9
rsbNotes.text: 55:9 divide their tongues. The psalmist alludes to the judgment the Lord brought upon the wicked generation who built the tower of Babel (Gen. 11:1–9).

verses.text: Day and night they prowl about on its walls; malice and abuse are within it.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 55:10
rsbNotes.text: 55:10 go around it on its walls. Lawless men are loose and active on the walls, the main defense of the city.

verses.text: Destructive forces are at work in the city; threats and lies never leave its streets.
If an enemy were insulting me, I could endure it; if a foe were raising himself against me, I could hide from him.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 55:11
rsbNotes.text: 55:11 its marketplace. This description of an ancient city of Israel, presumably Jerusalem during David’s reign, could be applied to today’s lawless cities.

verses.text: But it is you, a man like myself, my companion, my close friend,

rsbNotes.title: Ps 55:13
rsbNotes.text: 55:13 The terms become increasingly intimate, from “a man, my equal” to “my companion” to the climax, “my familiar friend.”

verses.text: with whom I once enjoyed sweet fellowship as we walked with the throng at the house of God.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 55:14
rsbNotes.text: 55:14 sweet counsel together. The worst hurt of all is that the close friend was a fellow worshiper in the house of God.

verses.text: Let death take my enemies by surprise; let them go down alive to the grave, for evil finds lodging among them.
But I call to God, and the LORD saves me.
Evening, morning and noon I cry out in distress, and he hears my voice.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 55:15
rsbNotes.text: 55:15 down to Sheol alive. That is, into Sheol, the grave.

verses.text: He ransoms me unharmed from the battle waged against me, even though many oppose me.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 55:18
rsbNotes.text: 55:18 the battle. While the psalm could conceivably have had its origin in battle, it is more likely that the battle is a metaphor for the struggles that the psalmist feels with his enemies and friends who surround him.

verses.text: God, who is enthroned forever, will hear them and afflict them- Selah men who never change their ways and have no fear of God.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 55:19
rsbNotes.text: 55:19 enthroned from of old. God hears the psalmist’s prayers from His kingly throne in heaven.

verses.text: My companion attacks his friends; he violates his covenant.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 55:20
rsbNotes.text: 55:20 his covenant. The psalmist describes the willful breaking of a formal agreement between friends. A covenant is a solemn agreement under sanctions.

verses.text: His speech is smooth as butter, yet war is in his heart; his words are more soothing than oil, yet they are drawn swords.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 55:21
rsbNotes.text: 55:21 smooth as butter . . . softer than oil. A powerful poetic description of hypocrisy and deceit.

verses.text: Cast your cares on the LORD and he will sustain you; he will never let the righteous fall.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 55:22
rsbNotes.text: 55:22 he will never permit the righteous to be moved. The context of the psalm shows that there is no unqualified promise that the righteous will always be happy and prosperous. The psalmist sings this lament to the Lord because he is in despair. The verse must mean that God will not leave the righteous in the fallen position forever, but will vindicate them in the end.

verses.text: But you, O God, will bring down the wicked into the pit of corruption; bloodthirsty and deceitful men will not live out half their days. But as for me, I trust in you.

rsbNotes.title: Ps 55:23
rsbNotes.text: 55:23 the pit of destruction. The grave.
